reviews.review_text: This is probably one of the most underrated games ever, just because of the saturation of shooters that happened during its release. But the reality is, that this specific shooter has very interesting features that the others don't have. Basically those would be:   A truth system with allies, with the possibility to choose between teammates. Unique enemies (just robots all the game, which its great). It feels a lot like Vanquish. A very interesting story. Yes, it really has a nice story. Who could have though something like that with a shooter? A lot of cinematics, some very lenghty ones. I don't know but it feels like a Hideo Hojima game sometimes.  All of this, maybe because the game was made by a japanese studio. So yeah, it's another shooter, but a very interesting one and unique. As I said, it remembers a lot to Vanquish, and obviously, Vanquish is better, but since there is no Vanquish on PC, this alternative is excellent, and should feel kinda enough for the ones that probably never gonna have the chance to play it.  The only problem that I really found with this game, was with issuing orders with your voice thorugh a mic. I'm just gonna say that it's better to ignore that feature and keep issuing orders like old school times, with Keyboard/Mouse or a Controller. You don't really need to issue orders with your voice, it's not necessary, and the game is still very enjoyable without that.

This game is complicated, REALLY complicated...  I installed it and played the rest of it (I had already played like 2 hours of it before on Steam) exclusively for a review that was asked. I didn't want to play it. The first 2 hours were terrible. I was crying of boredom...  It was too repetitive, too much handholding and linear, cutting from slow walking with stupid talking that didnt do any good to the combat, fighting 3 soldiers and going back to talking and pressing buttons. First 2 chapters are painfully terrible for me. 3 is better and 4 and so on are good and evolve into even better...   Anyways I finished Binary Domain and I can safely say it redeems itself after a while but it's still not trophy-winning. It truly is one of the best examples of 'It gets better as you go along'.  Ok into the review itself, Binary Domain is a game where you play as Adam Sandler in a robot filled world! And I can say the PC Port is outright ♥♥♥♥. Seriously, complete ♥♥♥♥. You have the 'Play' and 'Settings' Options before lauching the game. To configure the game: you have to pick the 'Settings' option, which will freak out and the window does not seem to be compatible with my Screen Native Resolution! How come, you ask? Well, you can tweak everything fine, BUT! The Save and Quit option is absolutely out of my reach because it's behind my taskbar so I cant press it, thus I have to fullscreen the settings window and THEN it has a small part of the button that is actually clickable!  Right now you're probably wondering: Wait, isn't that how Kane & Lynch 2 had it's options? Yes, you are correct BUT Kane & Lynch 2 also had the options in the game itself! So if the game needed tweaks you could change it without the need of quitting the actual game.   Binary Domain has a nice set of options, but the performance itself is decent and decent only! So if you need to tweak minor stuff, you have to quit the game, tweak it, boot it up, test it, if it's poor still, you have to exit, rinse and repeat.  It feels like the PC version of the game is a massive afterthought, which is sad.   The visuals themselves aren't bad though, particles effects are really well done, facial animation are a bit stiff but get the job done. Overall texture quality is decent as well. Regarding the visuals: THIS GAME HAS TOO MANY CUTSCENES! Some of them are completely useless and they weren't needed at all. So, it happens that I skipped some, *clicks skip* - *new cutscene appears* - *clicks skip* - *New... ok you get the point. If my memory doesn't fail me, the game can have 4 CUTSCENES IN A ROW! I swear the game could have half those cutscenes without hindering the game itself at all!  That being said, I must say the cutscenes are quite cliché but look genuinely good and some of the best cutscenes I could see in a video game. The action/story-important cutscenes, not the useless ones, those are boring and, again, useless!  Voice acting is rather cliché, but it's still cool as the game has a nice B-Movie feel with plenty of jokes and it works really well imo!  While the voice acting is simple, I can say Sandler's voice acting is actually REALLY GOOD! His facial animations and voice overs in cutscenes are really well done. The rest is a bit less memorable but still good overall. (Troy Baker plays Charlie in the game, I swear to God when I saw that in the credits, I was like 'lolwut...').   The game has that classic japanese poses and influence for sure. Almost everytime a cutscene ends, Adam makes that soldier pose with a badass face and then the shooting starts!  Combat: Adam's main rifle (which you cannot switch for another gun, it stick with you the WHOLE Game) is awesome! It feels great! Headshotting a robot is beyond satisfying and the secondary fire mode (Pulse Grenade Launcher-ish) is also a nice addition to the weapon. Everytime you kill an enemy you get points, more so for melee kills or headshot kills. Those point can be spent in medic kits (which dont heal you (the game has health regen), instead they revive you if you get downed), ammo or weapon upgrades for Adam's rifle or his companion's special weapon's...  AI is good.  Mr. Sandler's moving, however, is weird. When you get down stairs or a ledge you suddely move 4 times faster while getting down the stairs, sometimes you move so fast you actually run OVER the stairs and fly across them, which is hilarious!  When sprinting, you have trouble controlling Adam's body, which is fine except this ♥♥♥♥s up the running sequences, because stuff's falling, you're moving and dodging, except that you aren't because while sprinting it's tricky to move sideways, this makes the running away sequences poor and boring. P.S: You will die alot in them...  The cover system works well enough so kudos for that...  My biggest problem however is purely combat related: when shot, Adam can't stand the bullets going into his 1000 pounds battle power armor, so he flinches so f*cking much it's literally unbelievable! It makes the combat stiff! I remember a little test I did, I got shot by a 'boss' (not really a boss, but he had a mean-♥♥♥ sniper-rifle (those who played the game know who I'm talking about) and my character's aim literally moved 40 degrees to the right!   Trust me, it's fine to have flinch, it should have, but not this much! I mean, when a regular robot shoots you, your aim goes up too much for me, making the combat a little less fun than it should. However you can get back in cover, wait and get back into aiming and shooting. But still, this annoys the hell out of me.  Another huge issue is the stuns. The protagonist gets stunned/downed for everything! a grenade explodes 5 yards away *Tries to keep balance*.  *Robot clunkily bashes you with his fist* = *falls over and takes forever to get up*  It makes the pacing of the combat too stupidly slow, and this back and forth between shooting a magazine and falling over that is really annoying as for a small amount of seconds you have to stare at the computer, seeing Adam in an angel position on the floor!  Next up: the quicktime events! Trust me, there aren't many at all! BUT! The first time a quick time event in particular appeared, it has arrows and 2 space bar icons. I literally was 1 minute trying to figure it out before I failed and decide to plug in my controller and do it with the controller. I then got it.  Maybe I'm stupid in understanding coded messages but that was really weird to understand for me and it left me really frustrated.  Enouh of this. The combat is satisfying enough to carry the whole game alongside:   The story and the philosophy behind it. I will not even mention much about the story (You go on a top secret mission to investigate a big robot-making corporate), but the philosophy behind the game is really good and well done. It gives truly special moments to question out existance as humans and who we can have walking by our sides. This robot/human interaction in society is a good touch I never expected to get into me this much nor did I expect it to be this well fleshed out by the end of the game.  One last thing too, the plot twist behind this game. I read comments before going into the final chapter and some like 'Wow, plot twist was bat-sh*t insane, omg so cool*, it wasn't, I smelled the thing from miles away! Not sure if you, dear reader, will predict it too, but on my case, it disappointed me that I nailed what the twist was going to be.  Story is still pretty good, nothing too special, the philosophy behind it is what makes it stand out, though...  The game's length isn't bad either, it was 7.5-8 hours long for me, but I know friends who did it in 11 hours so it depends on the player. There's also multiplayer and a co-op wave based survival. Both are dead though survival can be played alone.  (Word Limit, gotta wrap up) It really gets MUCH better (from boring to fun), under 10€ is worth it for me... 6/10

Binary Domain is a third-person shooter developed and published by Sega. The story starts soon after an android attacked Bergen's headquarters, previously having no idea that he was a robot himself. Believing that robotics genius and founder of Amada corporation, Yoji Amada, created the robot, the International Robotics Technology Association (IRTA) sent one of their Rust Crews to Japan to find Amada and bring him in for questioning under orders from the UN Security Council. The gameplay is really fun to play. The player can issue commands to squad mates by pressing certain buttons or voice, via a headset. You can turn off the voice commands. The game features a consequence system, which decides how the squad views and trusts the player. Their opinion of the player is based on how the player performs and treats team members. This affects both the story and the gameplay, where the characters behave differently depending on trust levels. Conversations between the player and the squad members can also affect trust levels. The end of the game will change, depending on the level of trust the team members have in the player. Stats of both the player and the squad members can be augmented with nanomachines, as well as weapon upgrades, that can usually be bought at shops that the player can find throughout the game. The enemy AIs adjust themselves on how to fight back against the player's advance, depending on the situation. On the other hand, the squad AIs is pretty bad sometimes, walking in front of the player while firing. This is an overlooked title, I highly encourage anyone to at least try the demo.

The short review: It’s Gears of Wars with robots instead of aliens. If that premise disgusts you, the post-cyberpunk storyline could be enough to save the experience.  Binary Domain was published and developed by Sega, by the same internal team who brought us the Yakuza games for Playstation 2 and 3. The Yakuza games are essentially JRPGs with an open world veneer, a realtime hand-to-hand combat system set in a sprawling recreation of Tokyo and other Japanese locales with many people and things to interact with. So it’s a bit peculiar that the same team came out with something that may be considered “opposite” to that format: a linear, cover-centric third person shooter set in a beautiful yet sterile dystopian sci-fi world. So many third person shooters in this vein have popped up this past console generation. Some had you kill hordes of aliens (Gears of War series) while others had you mow down fields of Africans (Resident Evil 5) or the entire population of China (Kane & Lynch 2). Binary Domain presents the player with a different, less-fleshy kind of enemy to dismember and destroy: heartless robots and scraps of evil metal. It’s a refreshing change to be “killing” these scrap heaps, shooting their metal bodies and watching the various parts and components spark and hit the ground. The sensation is often invigorating, like smashing an empty aluminum can on your forehead or something (I’ve never done that before). The guns have a big, weighty feeling, like holding the big plastic guns from one of those old Sega light-gun arcade games such as Gunblade NY. And you can rest easy as they crumble to the ground, knowing that it’s only a soulless piece of machinery that you so ruthlessly filled with submachine gun bullets.   (...B-but, c-can I really destroy these creatures without any remorse???)  Binary Domain’s storyline is part Ghost in the Shell, part Terminator, part schlocky action-movie machismo. The main dude you play as, Dan, is somewhat charming and cool but also an idiot, as are many of the other squad members you interact with. The “romance” is laughably bad and I won’t mention any more of it. The real meat of the story deals with an arms race between two corporations to produce the most advanced robots, with one of those companies eventually creating a robot that could pass for a human. These robots come to be known as “Hollow Children” and their spread is feared by various governments. Your job, as part of a multinational coalition, is to go to Japan and find the original creator of the Hollow Children and bring him in for questioning.These Hollow Children have no idea they’re actually robots and can blend in a crowd with authentic skin, voices, and everything. Without giving too much away, this leads to a lot of fun questions and twists (Is he a robot? Is she a robot? Am I a robot?). Though it’s cool to see these themes touched upon, the game never really delves too much deeper into the ontology of man-made beings like the way the Ghost in the Shell film or other cyberpunk canon did. It’s here to give you a fun time, first and foremost. To quote a dialogue from a cutscene at the beginning of the game, an army man in a military boardroom ponders, “If it’s indistinguishable from humans, where does the machine end, and life begin?” which gets this response from a gruff comrade: “This is philosophical bull ♥♥♥♥.” The game’s narrative tips in the direction of that latter sentiment most of the time. We, the average consumer, like games because they let us toss plasma grenades at baddies and give us protagonists who leer at hot chicks, fistbump and make little jokes. Questions surrounding our increasingly digital existence seem at odds with the desire to let loose and have a bit of a good fun time. A philosophical challenge doesn’t give me the same kind of challenge that a huge robotic gorilla sub-boss does.  There is fun to be had, definitely. The bosses are huge, have unique designs and can be quite difficult. There’s a French robot who joins your team complete with a ridiculous accent. The guns feel good and the squad command system is kinda cool to tinker around with. But with all this emphasis on squads and teamwork, it’s really a shame that there’s no local or online co-op mode in the campaign. Maybe the developers want you to get close and share struggles and joys with the AI teammates, mirroring the way the human characters in the game’s narrative interact with the various robots and Hollow Children. I’m a cynic though, so I’ll chalk up the lack of co-op to a rushed development cycle or a design oversight.   Despite my complaints and exhaustion with the genre, Binary Domain is still better than the average third person shooter and worth a look. Its narrative is an entertaining mix of action and sci-fi, a good weekend thrill. The gameplay, while a bit derivative, is competent and has a few new neat mechanics to offer. So, go tear apart these robots limb by limb, have a small pondering session, and then quickly return to the fun of the violent sparks. Having fun is what separates us from those things, isn’t it?

Binary Domain is a nice surprise. Shooting mechanics are really well-devised, with an astounding mecha design and boss fight. An interesting and honest action/shooter, it should have worked more on the features that strive to set it apart from other games of the genre. But even in its current version, Binary Domain is fun and worth investing time into, especially if you are a fan of sci-fi and frenzied shooters.If you can get over the weak beginning the game will catch you – Binary Domain is a breathtaking shooter set in a Hollywood style. A must-have for all fans of 'robots-went-angry' situation.

This game's story is pretty cliché yet nicely told. The cutscenes are well done and the overall atmosphere is just great.  Your teammates can receive orders (optional by headset) and will remember your actions towards them which will also influence the ending of the game.  Ammunition and upgrades for weapons or your characters, can be bought at plenty of stations which are placed throughout the game.  You will fight against robots 99.9% of the time which makes 'tactical destruction' possible. So if you shoot a robot's head off, it will shoot at it's allys; if you remove it's legs it will crawl on the floor towards you; boss enemies have different weak points. The remains of robot parts also function as the currency in-game. Overall a very nicely done system.   From the technical side though there are several flaws:   The game is hard-coded to 16:9 resolutions, so you'll have black bars on monitors of another aspect ratio (pretty common for console ports nowadays though).   You also have an very annoying always-on mouse acceleration, which makes aiming with the mouse unnecessarily more difficult. For partly fixes visit  PCGW  [pcgamingwiki.com] ), but since you can't get completely rid of it, playing with a controller is recommended.  Worth mentioning is that you can change the field of view (which is imo very narrow by default).   If you can look over these issues, the game itself is great and definitely worth a playthrough or more.

Binary Domain starts out as an uninteresting shooter. Limited squad controls, useless speech commands and clumsy controls. The button mapping is the worst. They kept the merged keys, so usually there is one button for 2 or 3 actions which makes everything much worse. There are no graphics options, and almost no in-game options. As a port it is failed in so many ways. The graphics are serviceable. Characters look good from a distance, but closeup the poor texture quality can be seen. Regular robot enemies are looking okay, they lose a lot of scrap before die, which looks great. There are some sequences where it is almost like a terminator game. Locations are okay, sometimes a little bit too strict. There are many good designs in terms of bosses, which are a lot of here. Also, there are too many special sequences in the game. Otherwise, boss fights can be interesting and rather frustrating either. This is a mixed bag. The story itself is starting to get interesting after a few hours, but becomes quite a mess in the end. There are many cliched and cheesy scenes which are way out of track. The twists are pretty much foreseeable by anyone who used to watch movies. There is not much to say about it. In the 2/3 of the game there is a chance to select your teammates which will carry on with you. This adds some variety to the game. For example, I managed to select the robot with another one out of 5, then him out of 2 before a gas chamber room. He even said that he is not having a problem with the situation. There are various speech from squaddies during the missions which are spot on. They should had a lot of work with all the different dialogs. There are some 'rpg' elements also. You can buy upgrades for your mates, earn their trust by agreeing with them and leveling up their weapons. The options are pretty slim, but at least there are some.  Overall, I had a rough start, enjoyed the middle and got exhausted by the end. I played on normal, and I do say I am happy, because I had enough pain with the mechanics and the bosses. If you are into japanese sci-fi flicks and comfortable with a controller then you might have a good time, otherwise I would stay clear.   MY OPINION: 6.5/10 (AVERAGE)  Graphics: 8/10 World Design: 7/10 Gameplay: 6/10 Sound: 7/10 Replay Value: 6/10

Man, this reminds me how I miss playing those giant shooting arcade machines. You know the ones with the plastic machine guns and having to shoot off-screen to reload?  Well, this game makes me remember all those things. It's a TPSr that uses the old school arcade shooter formula incredibly.  The game is about a group of 'special ops' infiltrating japan to destroy a giant robotic conspiracy. The story isn't all that deep, it's pretty generic, however the execution is top-notch and most of teh characters are really charismatic and don't play much on the usual gruff characters most TPS tend to do.  The gameplay is incredible, I played using KB + M and it was incredibly responsive and since you'll mostly move to get a better shooting position, you'll be most of the time in a single covered place and shooting. The companions give proper cover and have a reasonably good AI. Shooting enemies in different spots make for different effects, you can take enemies' weapons. No complaints in this part.  It's kind of sad that multiplayer is mostly dead nowadays, but aisde from that, it's a great game.

If you can forgive the occasional muck up or glitch that makes you restart a checkpoint, the core combat and picking apart robots is fun, the challenges never get into the extreme, some fun side weapons make it even better, but I would have liked to see more customization options.

Binary Domain is almost one of the greats... Almost. All the action in the game - the shooting, the running etc. - is all satisfying. The weapons could use more kick, especially when hitting the limbs of an enemy. The bullets fired both look and feel small like they have no PUNCH! These things should have been large, hard-hitting objects that should have caused enemy limbs to jerk nearly half a foot, before coming to rest in the standard animation. Yet it's still fun to shoot off limbs and disable enemy robots. It just could have used more punch! Meanwhile, action sections are broken up with interactive social elevator rides, which allows the time and ability to talk to characters and teammates. But these are the most boring sections of the game, besides the story. It's interesting to hear some of the chatter sometimes though I think these sections are unnecessary. The game would have been better off throwing the story in the background and going straight up arcade. Where the story is still present, but the game isn't bogged down by the social events. Binary Domain would have been better as an arcade TPS (third-person shooter), but for what it is it's not bad.   Pick it up if you're interested in all the arcade aspects - the shooting, limb destruction, and action etc. - but, want something a bit more focused on story.

I had played the demo of this a while ago, and felt then that it had decent, if generic, third person cover-based shooter gameplay and a weird voice-activated squad command system that I didn't expect to use.  Turns out that that was a completely correct assessment that nevertheless managed to completely miss the point.  Binary Domain tells the story of a covert task force sent into Japan to investigate the source of Hollow Children, robots indistinguishable from humans that actually believe that they are human until they are activated. The perfect sleeper agents, who have been popping up across the world recently. All clues point to a mysterious robotics company, led by a director that hasn't been seen in public in decades.  If that feels generic then you would be correct, the game hits a bunch of tropes over the course of its ~15 hour campaign. In much the same vein your team doesn't consist of international characters, but rather of international stereotypes.  The arrogant American, the bro-tastic African American, the sarcastic Brit, the smooth French one, the stoic Chinese one. Players are unfortunately locked in as the arrogant American, but are free to choose which characters they bring on missions (up to two, only ones they've already encountered) which covers roles of the team that you don't want to take care of yourself. Don't feel like sniping? Bring the sniper. Prefer sniping instead? Leave her home and bring an assault character instead that will draw fire as you pick off enemy robots from a distance.  Yep, robots. All opposition you'll face, except for some very few exceptions, will be robotic creations of the robotics conglomerate. This might sound boring, but it allows for some very nice destruction systems where you can disable parts of your opponents, changing their behaviours. The generic humanoid variants will crawl around if you shoot off their legs and will start shooting their allies instead of you if you manage to shoot their heads off.  Your squad mates will comment on everything you do, from yelling out requests for assistance to compliments on successful takedowns to talking about recent plot developments. You are able to respond to these, theoretically by using voice commands but for the people that couldn't be bothered (like me) there are also keyboard / controller responses available. They way you interact with your squad mates will raise or lower their opinion of you which does... something.  I've only completed one playthrough, so I'm not quite sure what things could all have gone differently, but I feel that some squad members coming to my rescue and a romance subplot were optional things that I managed to trigger by which squad members I favoured. This means that my opinion of the ending that I got might be completely irrelevant to your potential playthrough, but I  REALLY  liked the ending.  In fact, my opinion of the game almost consistently got higher and higher from its slightly shaky start. Everything slowly ramps up until an admittedly very... classic, quite predictable final boss fight that I felt was very satisfying (and, as it should be, it is definitely the hardest fight in the game, at least it was for me).  If you feel like playing a fun, highly playable action game with some clever twists and turns that gets better if you stick with it, definitely give Binary Domain a try.
Tough story, interesting chars, exciting shooting robot, epic boss fight, multiple endings.  Recommend: playing this game with xbox 360 gamepad for best experience

First things first.  This game has the most atrocious mouse 'acceleration' I've ever encountered. It's actually a negative acceleration. So it moves faster the faster you move the mouse, up to a point, and then it moves slower. It's the most unnatural and awkward control I've ever experienced in a shooter. You will be over-adjusting or under-adjusting your aim constantly.  This alone might be a deal-breaker for some people. After playing through the whole campaign I was able to aim pretty well but still wasn't 'used' to it. I wasn't able to find a way to disable this 'feature'.   This game is silly.  Mostly in a good way. The term 'over the top' really wasn't in the developer's vocabulary. So, this is pretty awesome for ridiculous boss fights and mayhem. Some of which made me reminiscent of old school Contra games. One thing that is obvious though is that some set pieces are stolen directly from other games/movies. The biggest offenders being a canal sequence with a helicopter dropping mines on you (HL2). And a transformer chasing you that was directly ripped from Revenge of the Fallen. And a musical piece that is a carbon copy of Mona Lisa overdrive from Matrix 2. Combat with the stock enemies is fun. Getting headshots especially satisfying. The tactical 'commands' you can give your squadmates are limited, and there were a few instances where they were very much in the way. That said, they do actually kill enemies, which is a big step up from most companion AI in a lot of shooters (which is sad to say). The microphone command feature just plain did not work for me. It may have helped with immersion if it had, but it didn't.    Characters are very much on the nose racial and national stereotypes cranked to 11. The one black character in the game had Left 4 Dead's Coach's facial model directly ripped from that game (Possibly the same actor was used... but why use such an iconic face?) and even has a line about hating stairs... Direct reference to L4D2's intro movie. Expect a non-stop stream of 'aww hell naw's from him. Americans, insistently referred to as 'Yanks or Yankees', are loud, horny, aggressive, dumb, arrogant, religious and cocky. Apply suitable stereotypes to British, French and less so to Japanese and Chinese characters... You get the idea. If I were suppose to take this game seriously, then this might be borderline offensive, or at least eye-rollingly distracting. But since everything about this game is decidedly not serious, then it actually adds to the 'charm' of the experience.    The silliness of everything meant that the potentially deep philosophical issues of machine consciousness and all the moral implications that come along with that were only superficially examined. This is kind of a let down, but if it did turn too cerebral, it would have clashed pretty violently with the tone of the gameplay/characters.   Overall it was a fun ride, marred mainly by poor control issues.  8.5/10

I don't know what I expected going into this game. Maybe a mediocre game with laughable dialogue and good enough action to keep me interested. Instead, I think I got one of my suprise favorite games this year.  From the get-go, you'll realize how similar it is to Gears of War. Even the font looks the same for the HUD. And you'd be partly right. It does cover-based third-person shooting pretty competently. What I really enjoy is the story. Right from the get-go, it establishes the world with its 'Hollow Children', and, oddly enough, it feels natural. Being the makers of Yakuza, a franchise well-known for its story, I'm not too suprised. Maybe what sells it to me is the voice acting. They could've sent any old B-Team dubbers to pick this up, but instead we get Grade-A performances from Travis Willingham, Laura Bailey, and Troy Baker. Really, there isn't a person I can pick that was awful. It's kind of jarring that they use Japanese dialogue for the police (Which I enjoyed) but switch him to English when he talks to the party. And Johnny Yong Bosch trying to keep an accent with that was kind of strange, but almost endearing.  But this is a game, right? You're not here for the story! You want to shoot lots of scrap-heads! And that is also a fantastic time due to the limb system. Having tactics to maybe shoot approaching robots in the legs to slow them down while shooting heads off another group to start infighting makes the fighting unique to the genre. You will fight a lot of the same humanoid bots, but there still is a suprising amount of enemy variety, not to mention the boss fights. I was not expecting so many different boss fights, but they are certainly enjoyable.    One of the main advertised features of the game was voice commands, but honestly I didn't use them. My microphone is garbage, so that might have had something to do with the game not recognizing anything. You can opt to play without it, and I didn't feel very limited. There's a simple command list for your squad that does it's job. The affection system is interesting, and I was engaged in trying to max out my teammates. That might eventually lead you to min/max that stuff, but I recommend playing it blind the first time to see what outcome you take.  On a port scale, it looks stunning. I don't know about PC controls because I'm casual scum who plays with a controller, but that in itself was an enjoyable experience. No issues with inputs and all that.  I didn't try multiplayer. I don't even know if the servers are still up at this point, or if it's local like Space Marine. Apologies.  I'm almost a little worried giving this a glowing recommendation. I went in expecting schlock (Which it does feel kind of B-Movie sometimes- in a good way), or an unplayable mess, but I got a really engaging story and really enjoyable gameplay. Pick it up, and decide for yourself.

Binary Domain is a halfway decent 3rd person shooter with a LOT of rough edges and weird bits. I got it for free from a Sega promotion, and I would have been ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if I'd paid any actual money for it.  The shooter aspects of the game are fine, nothing spectacular but competently executed. I shot a lot of robots in the junk; can't complain about that. The boss fights are pretty fun, although they have a tendency to stunlock you in weird ways. The main character's assault rifle is upgradeable, and I was shredding robot limbs like leafy greens on a Food Network show by the end. There were one or two 'puzzle moments' where I had to use the gun's 'bosonic charge' or whatever to break barrels that weren't having any of this 'bullet' business.   There's some squad tactics and such, but this is a mess. There's a voice command feature that is a neat gimmick for about thirty seconds, as those things are wont to be. My squadmates rarely did anything useful, and at LEAST once per encounter they decided that standing between me and the enemy was a smart thing to do. If I get good kills, they compliment me, with the same phrase ad nauseum. All of them are just-this-side-of-racist caricatures of stereotypical nationalities. The French robot in particular stopped just short of going 'oh hoh hoh' at the end of every phrase. The dialog is pretty bad, and it's delivered pretty poorly to boot. The audio in cutscenes is poorly balanced, with the dialog being drowned out by the music.   The plot is... convoluted, full of holes, and becomes utter garbage in the last act. I caught bits and pieces of it, at one point they were talking about having sex with robots, there was a cutscene where I swear a dude was feeling up a rack of servers, and in another part there was a literal triple cross. A character changed sides and then changed sides again within the span of about 2 minutes.   Binary Domain is also a pretty awful console port. The mouse and keyboard controls are okay for the most part, but they're totally busted in several sequences involving fixed guns and a 'tank' sequence I hit at one point. I was throwing my mouse across the pad 5-10 times to get my character to turn 90 degrees in any direction. The gamepad controls might be better, but it didn't work with my Xbox One controller at all. Trying to move the camera just made it spin in circles. Often times, the button prompts were maddeningly nonspecific, telling me to press a mouse button but not which one, or just showing a '[_]' icon instead of a key.   So it's a halfway decent shooter with a lot of worthless experimental elements, terrible AI, an overly convoluted story, and it's a bad port of a console game. Metal Gear Solid fans will love it!

'Binary Domain' is a highly engaging and well-crafted shooter, where your marksmanship has a large bearing on how the battles play out - most of the time.  What I mean by the above is this: When an engagement revolves around the use of a bullet-fed weapon, an ability to land precise hits is well rewarded. You can immobilize enemies, get quick kills, and (in the case of opponents that are carried by flight modules) very literally get 'two birds with one stone.' The ability to hone your shooting technique and get quick positive feedback makes the majority of the game quite fun.  This title isn't without its flaws, though. You're often put into spaces where your ability to be really tactical is constrained. In some cases, I felt like the camera, environment, and weapon aim were all fighting for control. Also, most of the major setpiece battles feel just a touch 'overscripted.' Your shooting prowess ceases to be front-and-center, and instead takes a back seat to just following a set of cues. There are various trust-build/ trust-loss events that seem arbitrary or unfair (which is frustrating because of their relative importance), and the quicktime events don't seem to translate well to PC controls. The non-combat, quasi-RPG, 'walk around and talk to everything' sections seem to be somewhat awkwardly tacked on, and the conversation choices are sometimes cryptic in terms of what reaction they'll prompt.  Even so, the game is entirely decent. The story presentation gets a little 'overdramatic' at times, but it's generally a good yarn that stays away from outright cheesy territory. There are some very powerful (and even disturbing) moments that make it into the narrative; the script seems to have some real depth in spots. There are also some moments that are very definitely 'action-movie cliche,' but the game IS an action movie.  A fun action movie.  With some decent plot twists.  It's all worth a try.

Storylines:   Now the interesting aspect about what I just said, it was more like a US/UK western development started it, then was later finished by japanese development. This actually had a huge impact to its story development and characters development. Where western type of storybuilding tends to be more realism at face value with bit of hollywood action. Japanese storybuilding tends to be more about having humor and fan-service.  Those two don't mix... At all. It ruins the balance for what any gamers expect from it, wheither it's western or japanese gamer playing this. It's always going to leave a bad aftertaste once you had gone through its whole story. If you pay close attention to details, you can't help but wondering why some things in the story got so weird at times.  For this reason because western and japanese have their own storytelling media culture, completely molded into their comfort level. Without knowing what actually happened in the game development... I can only get the impression of what happened here. Maybe Sega was trying to please both sides? I don't know, but it's not good. It gave me 50/50 satisfaction through out the whole story. I didn't mean it's so-so or 'ok'... I meant half of the time is actually pretty damn good... but that other half was just sloppy. It's a pretty high contract level between the good and bad than just being bland.  I do understand japanese's culture but I felt like maybe it would be best if they didn't try to meddle with two cultures into one. It's very alienating as far it goes for my comfort level. Not forget to mention many different characters in the game are from different nations, they did try their best to retain their own culture from their own nation to justify their character development, but somewhere along the line, japanese cultures get mixed up with them. One moment, this character was acting very much like British... then next moment, acted very much like any typical japanese anime character without having to do with accepting culture nor reference to match that. So my impression was, someone created the story and then get finished by someone else, adding few more bits there and there to fill the story more.  However, it isn't to say that it doesn't have the good potential to become an very interesting franchise once they sorted out the story/gaming cultures. If you play games for the game play mechanics, then you might like this title. Binary Domain is a capable third person cover shooter. I used an Xbox 360 controller, and the controls reminded me a lot of Gears of War. This title also features an optional voice command system as a way of interacting with your AI squad members. An example would be telling them to 'Regroup', or responding to a conversational prompt such as 'I like you'. I felt that this was an interesting idea, but I wasn't able to get the voice recogonition to work reliably enough with my microphone to be able to actually use it during game play. These commands/responses can be issued with button presses, so the voice recognition isn't necessary. The main weapon of each character can be upgraded (Power, Rate of Fire, etc). Each character can also socket nanomachine modules for various passive upgrades (Defense +15%, Health Regen Rate +50%, etc.). Both types of upgrades are purchased at vending machines that are placed throughout the game, and the currency is accumulated each time an enemy is destroyed.  If you play games for the storytelling and like science fiction/cyberpunk, then you might like this title. All of the enemies are robots, so I never felt that disconnect of the main character being a good guy while at the same time killing scores of people. I felt that the voice acting was well done, and the dialog was mostly good as well.  The game world is mostly urban landscapes and building interiors, and I felt that the design and detail were pretty good. I was never distracted by anything. The character models are nicely detailed, and the animations are smooth and natural looking.   Besides failing to get the optional voice recognition working, the main issue I had with this title was that there aren't separate volume sliders for music, voices and sound effects. The only way to change the voume is through the configuration tool OUTSIDE of the game, which I thought was a very poor design decision.  Overall, I enjoyed my time with this title.

In Binary Domain, global warming has taken its toll on earth, burying cities all over the world. With millions upon millions of people dead, the task of rebuilding falls upon robots. The game sees you take the role of Dan, a wise cracking American who is a part of a task force known as a 'rust crew'. The rust crew is on a mission to determine whether the Amada company has broken clause 21 of the Geneva Convention - building robots that can pass as human.  In terms of gameplay, the movement and cover system feels like it is taken straight out of Gears of War, however, the gunplay is much more satisfying than Gears. Robots fall to pieces as you shoot them. If they lose a leg for example, they will claw their way towards you, if they lose their head, they will shoot other robots.  There are a few questionable sequences in the game (turret sections, amongst other things) but the good far outweighs the bad. It is a strong addition to anyone's library.
